title: About
text: Hi there! I’m Lexi, and I’m a junior studying sports media & advertising and public relations with a minor in communication studies at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, but I am originally from Olathe, Kansas. My Midwest roots influence all aspects of my life. I consider myself “Midwest nice” and can adapt to any weather change throughout the day! My passion for social media and content creation is the foundation of my work with the Barstool Viceroy program at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. I always find myself gravitating towards bold, unique creations that let me explore my passions more. As someone who grew up around sports, the culture, fanbase, and expereinces are what drive my passion for game day productions. I have always gravitated towards a sports-centered life and hope to work closely with sports post grad!

title: Is the Jim Harbaugh Effect Real? LA Chargers 2023-2024 season
text:
The LA Chargers had a horrible 2023 season. No playoffs, a 5-11 record and then a fired coach.


Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2

✔ purrr     1.1.0

✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()

title: Is Nebraska’s defense good enough to carry a struggling offense?
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)


── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.2
✔ ggplot2   4.0.0     ✔ tibble    3.3.0
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.1.0     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Code
logs <- read_csv("https://mattwaite.github.io/sportsdatafiles/footballlogs24.csv")


Rows: 1711 Columns: 54
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (8): HomeAway, Opponent, Result, TeamFull, TeamURL, Outcome, Team, Con...
dbl  (45): Game, PassingCmp, PassingAtt, PassingPct, PassingYds, PassingTD, ...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.




Code
logs <- logs |>
  mutate (PointDiff = TeamScore - OpponentScore)




Code
nu <- logs |>
  filter (Team == "Nebraska")
ggplot(nu, aes(x = reorder(Game, PointDiff), y = PointDiff, fill = PointDiff > 0)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip() +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#E41C38", "darkgray"), labels = c("Loss", "Win")) +
 labs(
    x="Games", 
    y="Point Differential for the 2024 season", 
    title="Nebraska's Tight Wins and Costly Losses", 
    subtitle="The Huskers had a close season of 7-6 with a Bowl Win. MORE", 
    caption="Source: Data Provider | By Lexi Shellhammer"
    ) +
  theme_minimal()









This visualization shows that while Nebraska won some games comfortably, they also lost several close ones, suggesting their overall record might look worse than their competitiveness in most games. It highlights how small margins made a big difference in their season outcome.


Code
teamsum <- logs |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |>
  group_by(Team)|>
  summarise(
    AvgPointsScored = mean(TeamScore),
    AvgPointsAllowed = mean(OpponentScore),
    AvgPointDiff = mean(TeamScore - OpponentScore),
    AvgYardsAllowed = mean(DefYards),   
    AvgYardsGained  = mean(OffensiveYards),
    TotalYardsGained = sum(OffensiveYards),
    TotalYardsAllowed = sum(DefYards),
    Wins = sum(Result == "W"),
    Games = n(),
    WinPct = Wins / Games
  )




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_point(data=teamsum, aes(x=AvgYardsAllowed, y=AvgPointDiff)) +
  geom_smooth(data=teamsum, aes(x=AvgYardsAllowed, y=AvgPointDiff), method="lm") +
 geom_point(data = subset(teamsum, Team == "Nebraska"),
             aes(x = AvgYardsAllowed, y = AvgPointDiff),
             color = "#E41C38", size = 2) + 
   geom_point(data = subset(teamsum, Team == "Indiana"),
             aes(x = AvgYardsAllowed, y = AvgPointDiff),
             color = "#990000", size = 2) + 
   geom_point(data = subset(teamsum, Team == "Purdue"),
             aes(x = AvgYardsAllowed, y = AvgPointDiff),
             color = "#CFB991", size = 2) + 
  geom_text(data = subset(teamsum, Team %in% c("Nebraska", "Indiana", "Purdue")),
            aes(x = AvgYardsAllowed, y = AvgPointDiff, label = Team),
            hjust = -0.2, vjust = 0.5, size = 3.5) +
expand_limits(x = max(teamsum$AvgYardsAllowed) * 1.05) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Nebraska’s Defense vs Point Differential",
    x = "Average Yards Allowed",
    y = "Average Point Differential"
  )


`geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'









The downward slope shows that teams allowing fewer yards (left side) generally have a higher point differential — they win by more points.
Teams that give up more yards (right side) tend to lose more often or by larger margins.
Nebraska’s dot is near the middle of the plot:
Their defense (around 320–330 yards allowed per game) is roughly average to slightly better than average for the Big Ten.
Their point differential (around +3 to +5) shows they’re barely outscoring opponents — competitive, but not dominant.
This chart supports a story like:
“Nebraska’s defense held opponents to relatively few yards, but that didn’t translate into big wins — their offense wasn’t efficient enough to turn a solid defense into comfortable margins of victory.”


Code
teamsum <- logs |>
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference") |>
  group_by(Team) |>
  summarise(
    AvgYardsGained = mean(OffensiveYards),
    AvgYardsAllowed = mean(DefYards)
  )

teamsum_long <- teamsum |>
  pivot_longer(
    cols = c(AvgYardsGained, AvgYardsAllowed),
    names_to = "Type",
    values_to = "Yards"
  ) |>
  mutate(Highlight = case_when(
    Team == "Nebraska" ~ "Nebraska",
    Team == "Indiana" ~ "Indiana",
    Team == "Purdue" ~ "Purdue",
    TRUE ~ "Other"
  ))


school_colors <- c(
  "Nebraska" = "#E41C38",  
  "Indiana" = "#990000",  
  "Purdue" = "#CFB991",    
  "Other" = "gray80"       
)


type_colors <- c(
  "AvgYardsGained" = "lightgrey",
  "AvgYardsAllowed" = "darkgrey"
)


ggplot(teamsum_long, aes(x = reorder(Team, Yards), y = Yards)) +

  geom_col(aes(fill = Type), position = "dodge", color = "white") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = type_colors,
                    labels = c("Offense (Yards Gained)", "Defense (Yards Allowed)")) +
  
  
  geom_col(
    data = subset(teamsum_long, Highlight != "Other"),
    aes(fill = Type, color = Highlight),
    position = "dodge",
    linewidth = 1.2
  ) +
  scale_color_manual(values = school_colors, guide = "none") +
  
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="Big10 Teams", 
    y="Average Yards Per Game", 
    title="Nebraska Defense Compared to Offense", 
    subtitle="The Huskers were the middle of the pact when \n it came to defensive yards allowed, but their \n offense did not keep up to win them games.", 
    caption="Source: Data Provider | By Lexi Shellhammer"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "right",
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold", size = 14)
  )









Nebraska’s offense (yards gained) is lower than its defense (yards allowed)* — meaning they generally didn’t move the ball as effectively as they stopped opponents.
Nebraska’s defense limited opponents’ yardage better than most, but their offense struggled to gain yards. This imbalance helps explain why Nebraska may have lost several close games — the defense performed well enough to win, but the offense couldn’t produce enough scoring opportunities.


Code
big10 <- logs |> filter(Conference == "Big Ten Conference")




Code
ggplot() + 
  geom_hline(yintercept=5.217241, colour="red") + 
  geom_line(data=big10, aes(x=Date, y=DefAvg, group=Team)) + 
  facet_wrap(~Team) +
  labs(
    x="Date", 
    y="Defensive Yards Allowed", 
    title="Defense Averages of Big10 Teams", 
    subtitle="The Huskers started off strong with a limited number \n of defenseive yards allowed, then something went wrong...", 
    caption="Source: Data Provider | By Lexi Shellhammer"
    )
